Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: I stared at the kitchen calendar, my granddaughter’s careful handwriting circling today’s date with hearts and smiley faces. Our family gathering was something I’d promised not to miss—an afternoon of laughter, stories, and the warmth only family can bring. I could already picture my youngest grandchild tugging at my sleeve, eager to show me her latest drawing. But as I set out the plates, my phone rang. It was Miriam, her voice trembling. Her father, a beloved member of our congregation, had just passed away. The family needed me to officiate the funeral, and the only time that worked for everyone was this afternoon. I heard the pain in her voice, the expectation that I would be there to guide them through their grief, as I always had. My heart twisted. My family needed me, but so did my community. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my presence, each deserving it. I stood in the kitchen, torn, the clock ticking louder with every passing second.
